doc.title: Post- rally risk assessment: After plunging \(15\%\) during February- April, the MXAPJ index has rallied over \(30\%\) without a meaningful pullback. Earnings downgrades have stabilized, but valuation
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/Asia-Pacific Portfolio Strategy Are markets too complacent Introducing RADaR Regional Asia Drawdown Risk modelAsia-Pacif_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: Post- rally risk assessment: After plunging \(15\%\) during February- April, the MXAPJ index has rallied over \(30\%\) without a meaningful pullback. Earnings downgrades have stabilized, but valuations and market technicals are extended. This is an opportune time to assess the likelihood and magnitude of a regional correction.

Asian markets need a tailored approach to assess drawdown risks: Our cross asset team's equity drawdown risk model assesses the likelihood of a drawdown in global equity markets using developed market variables. To complement this, we assess drawdown risk for Asian regional equity markets given differing sensitivities around macro factors, more frequent and deeper levels of historical drawdowns in Asia than in developed markets, and idiosyncratic factors.

Characteristics of drawdown risks in four dimensions: 1) Market technicals, 2) Valuations, 3) Macro & earnings fundamentals and 4) Cross- asset & idiosyncratic factors. These input factors also need to be transformed to be more suitable for identifying the region's drawdown risks.

Introducing RAdar: Combining nearly 30 variables, our new Regional Asian Drawdown Risk model for equity markets indicates that drawdown risk probability over a 12m horizon has increased to elevated levels across a moderate drawdown range of \(- 10\%\) and \(- 20\%\) . However, the risk of a severe drawdown in excess of \(20\%\) remains low. Despite heightened moderate drawdown probability, when severe drawdown probabilities are low, risk- adjusted returns tend to be favorable over a 12- month horizon. This supports a "buy the dip" approach in the event of a correction in regional equities.

Add puts/put spreads: As indicated in our recent regional report, for investors able to do so, we suggest adding core exposure with 3m \(95\%\) puts or 3m \(95 / 85\) put spreads on regional indices (M1APJ or MXEF) or more liquid individual market alternatives (e.g., HSI or HSCEI) as a way to protect against a potential moderate pullback, maintain core positions, and prepare for the seasonally strong 4Q. Our cross- asset team also recently flagged puts on selective EM and European equities which look attractive to hedge a potential sell- off there.

After plunging \(15\%\) from the Feb 21 high to the low on Apr 9, the MXAPJ index has staged a notable rally since "Liberation day," with broad- based gains across major indices without even a \(5\%\) pullback. This steady rise reflects improving tariff clarity and loosening financial conditions. However, given the lack of any correction over the past nearly five months and stretched valuations and market technicals, market participants are increasingly wondering whether a drawdown may lie in store.

Historically, prolonged rallies without a meaningful correction tend to raise the probability of a short to medium- term pullback, particularly when accompanied by signs of complacency in sentiment and reduced downside hedging. In addition, as noted in our recent report, the tactical outlook for regional equities is clouded by adverse seasonality and extended price momentum. The August- September period is typically the worst for the MXAPJ index performance \((- 4\%\) on average) and most of its constituent markets. This sets the stage for 4Q, which is usually the best quarter of the year. Thus, now is an opportune time to assess the likelihood and magnitude of a regional market correction. Leveraging the work of our global strategy team, we introduce a drawdown framework which may help investors address such risks in a more systematic manner.
Exhibit 1: After plunging \(15\%\) from the Feb 21 high to the low on Apr 9, the MXAPJ index rallied without a meaningful correction
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 2: Asian equity markets have broadly gained more than Q1 drawdown
Source: FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 3: August-September period is typically the weakest 2-month period in the year, while 4Q is the best quarter
Note: Based on MSCI Index Local FX Returns except MXAPJ (US\$)
Exhibit 4: RSI has reached extended levels with mild divergence
Source: MSCI, FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Our global strategy has constructed an equity drawdown framework for global equity markets using developed market inputs. However, Asian regional equity markets have different sensitivities to macro factors and more frequent and deeper drawdown levels than developed markets, suggesting that a global risk framework may not fully capture the idiosyncratic drivers of regional drawdowns.

To illustrate this divergence, the S&P 500 index has had 13 and 6 cases of moderate \((10\% - 20\%)\) and severe \((>20\%)\) drawdowns respectively since 2008. The MXAPJ index has had 27 and 11 such drawdown cases during this same period, reflecting higher macro sensitivity and market structure differences. The average duration period for moderate drawdown cases has also been shorter than in the US equity market, reflecting the region's higher volatility. Despite such frequent cases, Asian equity markets have not had a meaningful drawdown for nearly 5 months.

Given these distinctions and the lack of drawdown recently, we believe that a region- specific model is essential to capture the risk profile of Asian equities, rather than applying a global framework without any customization.
Exhibit 5: MXAPJ Index had more frequent and deeper drawdowns than the US market
Source: MSCI, FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 6: Asian equity markets have not had a drawdown more than 5% for nearly 5 months
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 7: The proportion of MXAPJ constituents experiencing meaningful drawdowns has declined as well
Source:FactSet,MSCI,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

To better understand the drivers of drawdown risks, we classify input factors into four categories: market technicals, valuations, macro & earnings fundamentals, and cross- asset & idiosyncratic factors. While these inputs provide useful signals as raw data, our analysis suggests that transformation of the raw data can make them more suitable for identifying MXAPJ regional drawdown risks.

We apply a series of transformations and correlation tests across the factor set. This process involves rolling- window statistics, momentum calculations, and z- score adjustments aimed at enhancing the predictive power of the inputs in signaling market stress. By transforming the data, we uncover latent relationships that are often obscured in unprocessed datasets, thereby improving the accuracy of our assessment of drawdown risks.

The table below highlights the correlation between different input transformations and 12- month forward returns. Across categories such as market technicals, valuations, macro fundamentals, and idiosyncratic indicators, we find that different forms of transformation yield a clearer perspective on potential drawdown risks over the next 12 months.
Exhibit 8: Correlation of transformed input factors with MXAPJ 12 month forward returns

Note: Due to limited data after the most correlated transformation, \\* denotes variables use the 2nd most correlated transformation.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Several factors stand out given their strong correlations with 12m future market returns. Their latest readings suggest that potential drawdown risks could emerge going forward.

As the April drawdown most recently demonstrates, sharp increases in volatility combined with oversold relative strength index (RSI) levels signal positive asymmetry for regional market returns. Specifically, when the MXAPJ RSI falls below 45, subsequent 12- month average returns exceed \(13\%\) (Exhibit 9), while returns tend to weaken as RSI rises and becomes extended. Currently, however, risk asymmetry appears less supportive. The regional market's RSI has risen above 65, trailing 12m returns are high at \(16\%\) , and the US VIX has retreated below 15, conditions that historically point to elevated downside risks given extended technical positioning and stretched momentum signals. From a valuation perspective, regional market fP/B valuation on a 3yr z- score basis shows a \(- 66\%\) correlation with 12- month forward returns and now stands close to \(+2\) standard deviations.

Market- implied growth factors are negatively correlated with forward regional equity returns on a 3- year z- score basis: when implied growth is extended, subsequent returns tend to weaken. (For detail on methodology of market implied growth factors, see Global Markets Analyst: Tracking and Trading Risks in the Corona- Crisis.) Currently, market implied growth factors are pricing above \(+1\) S.D, suggesting an extended setup. Meanwhile, US growth signals are deteriorating, notably the Conference Board Leading Economic Index, which correlates strongly with Asian forward equity returns (Exhibit 12).

Following a series of trade agreements announced by the US and its key trading partners, global economic policy uncertainty (EPU)- which spiked sharply in the first half of this year- has since eased, falling by more than 3 S.D. from the April peak. Historically, elevated EPU levels have been associated with better forward equity performance asymmetry. However, our VAR model shows Asian equities have risen more than would be expected by the reduction in policy uncertainty, in turn suggesting a less favorable forward return set- up for regional markets.
Exhibit 9: Extended contrarian indicators and trailing returns imply weaker forward risk-reward

Exhibit 13: Economic policy uncertainty has eased from April's peak...
Source:FactSet,MSCl,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Source: PolicyUncertainty.com, MSCI, FactSet, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 12: The US leading economic index correlates well with forward regional equity returns and suggests a potential drawdown
Source:FactSet,MSCl,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 14: ... but Asian regional markets have priced the reduction in policy uncertainty more than our VAR model indicates
Source:Haver Analytics,The Conference Board,FactSet,MSCl,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Note: Valuations of JP/HK/TW/KR Markets have expanded more than \(30\%\) since the trough

While individual factors provide useful signals regarding forward equity returns, they are not perfectly correlated with drawdown risks. Exhibit 15 illustrates the current probability of a \(>20\%\) drawdown in the next 12 months, as implied by univariate logit regressions across individual factors. At an individual level, valuation extension and weakening US implied growth emerge as the most concerning indicators. To evaluate our logit models, we use precision and recall metrics. Precision measures the proportion of correct drawdown predictions out of all drawdown predictions made by the models while recall measures the proportion of actual drawdown cases that the models correctly identified. Even for stronger factors, however, precision and recall metrics highlight the limitations of relying on single- variable signals. As average precision and recall metrics to measure accuracy of the positive signals from univariate logit models show \(40\%\) and \(20\%\) levels respectively, predicting potential downside risks solely based on individual data does not guarantee successful forecasts.

Exhibit 15: Extended valuations and weakening US growth give the highest indication of drawdown risk for regional markets, but the precision of individual indicators is low Implied moderate drawdown probability of a \(12m\) max drawdown \(> - 10\%\) ranked by drawdown probability

Note: (1) Precision (True Positive (TP)/ (True Positive (TP) \(^+\) False Positive (FP)) measures the accuracy of the positive predictions made by the model; Recall (True Positive (TP)/ (True Positive (TP) \(^+\) False Negative (FN)) measures the ability of the model to identify positive instances
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

To move beyond individual signals and systematically assess the probability of future market drawdowns, we develop a multi- variate logistic regression (logit) model that integrates these factors and captures their joint relationship with forward returns. This framework, dubbed RADaR (Regional Asian Drawdown Risk), is designed to estimate the likelihood of experiencing varying drawdown ranges over a 12- month horizon, based on historical patterns and evolving market conditions.

We classify forward- looking maximum drawdown risks into four different ranges: no drawdown (less than \(- 5\%\) ), shallow drawdown (- \(5\%\) and \(- 10\%\) ), moderate (- \(10\%\) and \(- 20\%\) ) and severe (- \(20\%\) ) categories over a 12- month window. To account for the temporal structure of financial data, we used a rolling window approach for model

training and validation, preserving the time-series integrity and avoiding look-ahead bias. More importantly, since potential drawdown risks often stem from different market narratives rather than single input factors, our analytical framework emphasizes the interaction of extended market technicals, valuations, and macro cycle dynamics in shaping the probability of future corrections.
Less than \(- 5\%\) and shallow drawdown risks have fallen to low levels after spiking earlier this year. This is because shallow drawdown risk has been subsumed into moderate drawdown risk.
Moderate drawdown risks have risen meaningfully, with probabilities increasing over the past four months.
Severe drawdown risks remain relatively low, with only a marginal uptick. The likelihood of \(>20\%\) drawdowns remains contained in the current environment.

Each drawdown model has predicted subsequent regional drawdowns well when the model rises above \(50\%\) , as demonstrated by higher precision and recall metrics than those of univariate models (Exhibit 19). Although the models are calibrated on a 12- month horizon, the empirical results show the largest average maximum drawdowns tend to occur on within 1- 3 months.
Exhibit 16: Shallow drawdown probabilities are currently low
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 17: Moderate drawdown risks have risen steadily over the past five months
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 18: Severe drawdown risks remain low despite a recent uptick
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 19: Our drawdown models predicting different ranges of drawdowns exhibit decent predictive power for corresponding drawdown risks

To further improve the accuracy of our drawdown models, we take the average of moderate and severe probabilities. When this average probability is above \(40\%\) , the predictive power for subsequent drawdowns in the near- term is high. The precision metric, which measures accuracy of actual drawdowns predicted by our drawdown model, has been close to \(90\%\) over the next 3- month horizon and higher than precision metrics from individual drawdown models. Currently, the average moderate and severe drawdown probability has risen close to \(50\%\) driven by elevated moderate drawdown probability, which suggests risk of a pullback in regional markets.

Exhibit 20: Currently, the average moderate and severe drawdown probability has risen close to \(50\%\) driven by elevated moderate drawdown probability, which suggests risk of a pullback in regional markets.
As both moderate and severe drawdown models are mutually exclusive, the maximum value of average probability is \(50\%\)
Exhibit 21: When the average of moderate and severe drawdown probabilities is above \(40\%\) , the predictive power for subsequent drawdowns in the near-term is high
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

To help investors monitor risks from individual factors, we show where input factors are in percentile terms from 2009 until the present (Exhibit 22). As noted, RSI, price moving average deviation, and valuation are indicators that suggest higher risk of a drawdown.
Exhibit 22: Technicals and valuations seem extended considering their negative correlation with forward returns

The risk of a moderate drawdown appears elevated currently, driven largely by extended market technicals and valuations. However, if the region was to experience a pullback, these factors would self- correct and the low probability of a severe \((>20\%)\) drawdown would point to an improved return profile over a 12- month horizon. This points to a "buy the dip" approach to markets.

From a strategic perspective, improved policy clarity from trade agreements and expected monetary policy accommodation from the Fed and regional central banks support our positive core view on Asian regional equity markets. Moreover, investor positioning remains conservative. We remain constructive on Asian equity markets over a 12- month horizon.
Exhibit 23: Severe drawdown probabilities below \(10\%\) historically have resulted in favorable risk-adjusted returns over a 12 month horizon
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 24: Global active mutual funds remain sharply underweight Asia ex-Japan in absolute terms and relative to their 10-yr average exposure
Source: EPFR, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 25: Foreign investors have only rebought a third of their aggregate selling of EM Asia since mid-2024; light positioning may cushion the extent of a potential pullback in a seasonally weak September period
Source: Bloomberg, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

To hedge against the risk of a drawdown that our models are pointing to, we suggest adding short- dated puts or put spreads for investors who are able to do so. As observed recently by our cross- asset team, puts on selective EM and European equities also look attractive to hedge a sell- off. More specifically, implied volatility has moderated, which lowers the cost of put protection: 3m 95% put costs for many regional markets are towards the lower end of their respective one year ranges and returns on premia if markets fall 10% or return to 3m lows look attractive in most cases. 95/85% put spreads can lower the premium cost further, have attractive maximum payout potential, and align with our view that potential pullbacks are likely to be moderate given the constructive fundamental outlook for the region along with light foreign investor positioning. Investors could consider hedges on the MXAPJ index or the broader MSCI emerging markets index (where Asia is 80% of index weight), which has a more liquid options market. Regional indices with more liquid options include HSI and HSCEI.
Exhibit 26: Implied volatility has declined, lowering the cost of downside protection
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 27: Returns on premia for 3m 95 puts look attractive for most markets in the event of a \(10\%\) correction; Put spreads can lower premium cost further and have attractive maximum payout potential
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 28 reports the t- stats and goodness- of- fit measures for the univariate logit models estimated on the severe drawdown model. In out- of- sample dataset, the combined multivariate severe drawdown model achieves an AUC score of \(71\%\) . By comparison, the average AUC across individual variables is only \(54\%\) , underscoring the difficulty of predicting equity drawdowns when relying on single variables rather than the combined multivariate model.
Exhibit 28: T-stat and goodness-of-fit measures for the univariate logit models estimated on the severe drawdown model

Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

This research is for our clients only. Other than disclosures relating to Goldman Sachs, this research is based on current public information that we consider reliable, but we do not represent it as accurate or complete, and it should not be relied on as such. The information, opinions, estimates and forecasts contained herein are as of the date hereof and are subject to change without prior notification. We seek to update our research as appropriate, but various regulations may prevent us from doing so. Other than certain industry reports published on a periodic basis, the large majority of reports are published at irregular intervals as appropriate in the analyst's judgment.

Goldman Sachs conducts a global full- service, integrated investment banking, investment management, and brokerage business. We have investment banking and other business relationships with a substantial percentage of the companies covered by Global Investment Research. Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, the United States broker dealer, is a member of SIPC (https://www.sipc.org).

Our salespeople, traders, and other professionals may provide oral or written market commentary or trading strategies to our clients and principal trading desks that reflect opinions that are contrary to the opinions expressed in this research. Our asset management area, principal trading desks and investing businesses may make investment decisions that are inconsistent with the recommendations or views expressed in this research.

We and our affliates, officers, directors, and employees will from time to time have long or short positions in, act as principal in, and buy or sell, the securities or derivatives, if any, referred to in this research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
